summary: This compilation from the 1989–1990 Review of Ghana Law reports several personal injury cases, primarily arising from road accidents resulting in fatalities. The courts awarded damages based on loss of dependency, loss of expectation of life, funeral expenses, pain and suffering, and special damages. Awards varied significantly depending on the deceased's income, number and age of dependants, and duration of survival post-accident. For instance, in APPIAH v BAFFOUR, a driver's death led to a GH4,680,000 award, including GH4,000,000 for loss of dependency. Even minors with income, such as a 17-year-old coalpot maker in KOOMSON v EDU, received compensation for loss of expectation of life. The judgments reflect structured assessment of economic and non-economic losses, with some courts factoring in tax implications and costs separately.
verdict: Plaintiffs awarded damages in all reported cases.

rationaleHighlights: Awards based on deceased's income, dependants' ages, and years of expected support
Loss of dependency calculated using multi-year purchase method
Loss of expectation of life awarded even for minors with earning capacity
Funeral and medical expenses reimbursed as special damages
Pain and suffering recognized in fatal cases with brief survival
Tax implications considered in one award (NARH v TEYE)
confidenceNotes: All data extracted directly from cited Ghanaian legal reports; awards and reasoning are explicitly stated in the source.
